Usage¶

Installation¶

I mean, really don’t try to do this, because it will fail. And if it doesn’t fail, who knows what will happen…

$ conda install dinosaur

Discovering dinosaurs¶

Because everyone likes dinosaurs. Until they escape. That’s what Jurassic Park taught us at least.

dinosaurs.random_dinosaur(food=None)¶

Returns a random dinosaur. If food given, refines the returned dinosaur to be one that eats that kind of food. Well, it doesn’t refine the dinosaur, more narrows down the possible dinosaurs that could be returned. And it doesn’t even do that, because the code is not here. It’s all a myth. Including dinosaurs…

Parameters

  • food (str, list[str], or None) – Optional. What does the dinosaur eat?

  • food2 (str) – Not really.

Returns

A dinosaur. Like, an actual live one.

Return type

str. Not really a live one.

dinosaurs.trex()¶

Returns T-Rex. That’s it. Not as exciting as random_dinosaur()

Returns

T-Rex

Return type

str

Dragons?¶

I know, not dinosaurs, but equally as cool.

dragons.random_dragon(fire=True)¶

Returns a random dragon. Possibly fire-breathing. If you still want dinosaurs, go to dinosaurs()

Parameters

fire (Bool. Default True) – Optional. Does the dragon breathe fire?

Returns

Dragon. (Ha, just kidding…)

Return type

str

Dinosaurs
